intro: Panax boivinii, commonly known as the Boivin ginseng, is a rare and endangered plant native to the mountainous regions of southern China. It belongs to the Araliaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces red berries that contain seeds, which are dispersed by animals. Due to its limited distribution and habitat destruction, it is critically endangered and requires conservation efforts to survive. Its botanical significance lies in its potential medicinal properties and its role in ecological studies.
